frameDefinitions: An object (the Theme) moves away from a Source.
An Entity exists at a particular Location, at a particular Time, as observed by an implicit observer.
An Experiencer, Expressor, Event, or State has an emotion as brought on by an Stimulus or Topic.
A Person takes leave from his or her routine Activity (such as work or school) for a Duration of time.
An object Theme moves in the direction of a Goal.
A New filler occupies a Role or serves a Function after the Old filler ceases to occupy the position.
frameExamples: Liquid water was <t>present</t> on the surface of Mars billions of years ago.
The <t>joyful</t> reunion took place on Sunday.
The claimant should then submit medical certificates for the duration of their <t>absence</t> from work.INI
Some students <t>arrived</t> at the school on Sunday.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the object which moves. It may be an entity which moves under its own power, but it need not be.

All the verbs in this frame express some change of location, away from one place and to another. Any constituent that expresses the initial position of the <fen>Theme</fen>, before the change of location, is tagged with <fen>Source</fen>. Often the <fen>Source</fen> is understood from context.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the departure takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location in which the departing takes place.
The <fen>Entity</fen> whose existence at the <fen>Location</fen> is confirmed.
The <fen>Location</fen> of the <fen>Entity</fen>. The <fen>Location</fen> is conceived as a ground for an event of inspection to determine the presense of the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Entity</fen> is present at the <fen>Location</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen>, <fen>Expressor</fen>, <fen>Event</fen>, or <fen>State</fen> can be described as having said emotion.
The person who is absent from his or her <fen>Activity</fen> for a <fen>Duration</fen> of time.
This role describes the activity or responsiblilities from which the <fen>Person</fen> is taking a temporary leave.
The amount of time the <fen>Person</fen> is absent from his or her <fen>Activity</fen>.  This can also be expressed as a description of a duration, as shown below:
The time at which the leave occurs.
<fen>Theme</fen> is the object that moves. It may be an entity that moves under its own power, but it need not be.
<fen>Goal</fen> is any expression that tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up, or would end up, as a result of the motion.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when arriving occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the arriving event occurs.
The new filler of the <fen>Role</fen> that was previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen> filler.
The category that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities fit into as a result of the <fen>Function</fen> they serve.
The (generally desirable) state of affairs that the <fen>New</fen> and <fen>Old</fen> entities are involved in bringing about.
The entity that occupied the <fen>Role</fen> or served the <fen>Function</fen> before the <fen>New</fen> filler.
The time at which the <fen>New</fen> takes up the <fen>Role</fen> previously occupied by the <fen>Old</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The officer</fex> left the house.
The woman left. <fex>DNI</fex>
We left <fex>in the morning</fex>.
At Medicine Man's ragtime dance contest, a jubilant <fex>girl</fex> drove the crowd wild.
Earl is jubilant <fex>about his new swim trunks</fex>.
<fex>Putin’s initiative</fex> caused joyful excitement in Baku on Friday.
He met me with a glad <fex>face</fex>.
Armed officials marred the joyful <fex>mood</fex> at the recent Mon festival in Samut Sakhon.
I am helping them to have the joyful <fex>birth</fex> they want.
During his <fex>wife's</fex> absence, Linkworth and his mother had another violent argument.
Such conditions would be likely to lead to absence <fex>from work</fex>.
Dissuaded from resigning, Macmillan took <fex>extended</fex> leave rather than restrain his public utterances.
Columbus took leave of the known world <fex>on 6 September 1492</fex>.
<fex>The officer</fex> approached the house.
We arrived <fex>in Paris</fex> before midnight.
The traditional thatched roof has often been replaced <fex>by corrugated galvanized iron</fex>.
What gas replaced Hydrogen <fex>as a safer medium for use in balloons</fex> on account it does not burn?
Oil and gas replaced coal <fex>in heating homes, in industry, and in transportation</fex>.
The electron was discovered and <fex>electricity</fex> replaced gas lamps.
When electricity replaced oil <fex>in the early 1930's</fex>, the steady beam was replaced by a flashing light.
